result.execSummary:
The defendant Takiera Takeya Stephens was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Misappropriate ID Info - Obtain Money, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.201(2)(a).
  • Misappropriate ID Info - Obtain Money, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.201(2)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Court allows transfer of probation to the State of Illinois

miscConds.notes: $1,478.00 owed. State to contact victims to determine who is owed restitution. State also needs to provide the court with extradition costs which will be added to the current amount of restitution owed.

BOTH COUNTS: Provide a DNA sample; pay the related surcharge. Pay court costs and all applicable surcharges and assessments to be collected during term of probation. If defendant is revoked, all applicable surcharges and assessments are to be collected by DOC from up to 25% of prison funds. Non-payment penalty shall be a civil judgment.
Pay all supervision fees.

- Obtain/maintain employment.
- Obtain GED or HSED.
Court advised defendant that as a convicted felon she may no longer use or possess any firearms; also she may not vote in any election until her civil rights have been restored.

- No new law violations rising to the level of probable cause.
- No alcohol or controlled substances.

- Cooperate with agent.
- Cooperate with any correctional programs recommended.
- Follow all rules of probation and extended supervision.

- AODA assessment and any recommended treatment.
- Absolute sobriety with random urine screens and breathalyzers .

timeConds.notes:
STRAIGHT TIME. No Good Time Credit. Defendant to report to HOC on 03-17-16 at 5pm.

**Defendant was suppose to check into Probation/Parole after court sentence. Defendant provided a DNA sample and by the time she completed this task, the Probation/Parole Dept. was closed. As defendant lives in Chicago, court allows for defendant to check into Probation/Parole on the day she is to report to HOC on 03-17-16.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: Count 1, with credit for 34 days time served

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Takiera Takeya Stephens

4/29/16 restitution notice/affidavit mailed to victim.
Bail refund
Attorney Robert E Haney in court.  Ronald Dague appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant checked into the House of Corrections.  No further action needed.
3/30/16 bail refund notice/affidavit mailed to surety.
Amended Judgment of Conviction to be done providing the name of the institution in which the restitution is owned - Barclays Bank; and $0 for extradition costs.

Letter from ADA Thomas Potter indicating that the bank in which the $1,478.00 restitution is owed is Barclays Bank.  Also, the District Attorney's Office did not incur any expenses relating to the extradition of defendant.  Extradition fees set at $0.

Contact from Attorney Robert Haney.   Defendant was to check into Probation/Parole after Court sentenced.  Defendant provided a DNA sample and by the time she completed this task, the Probation/Parole department was closed.  As Defendant lives in Chicago, Court allows for Defendant to check into Probation/Parole on the day she is to report to the House of Corrections, March 17, 2016.

Defendant Takiera Takeya Stephens in court with attorney Robert E Haney.  Thomas Potter for  Ronald Dague appeared for the State of Wisconsin.   Pursuant to plea negotiations, and on motion of the State, Court ordered COUNTS 2 and 4 be DISMISSED to be used as READ-INS on COUNTS 1 and 3.   Defendant changes plea to GUILTY to COUNTS 1 and 3.  Defendant examined as to her plea, advised of her Constitutional rights and the maximum penalty. Court found that defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived her rights. Plea questionnaire received and filed. Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea. Court found defendant guilty on COUNTS 1 and 3 as charged in the information and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record.  Court advised the defendant that as a convicted felon she may no longer use or possess any firearms; also she may not vote in any election until her civil rights have been restored.  

Sentencing proceeded.  Statements made by State, Defense and Defendant.  

AS TO COUNT 1:
The Court sentenced defendant to serve a term of IMPRISONMENT in the Wisconsin State Prisons for 3 1/2 YEARS.  INITIAL CONFINEMENT of 1 1/2 YEARS and EXTENDED SUPERVISION of 2 YEARS, with credit for 34 DAYS time served.  Court STAYED sentence and placed the defendant on PROBATION for a period of 2 YEARS with the following conditions for probation and extended supervision:
Defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and is not eligible for the Wisconsin Substance Abuse Program.  
-Restitution in the amount of $1,478.00 owed.  State to contact victims to determine who is owed restitution.   State also needs to provide the Court with extradition costs which will be added to the current amount of restitution owed.  
-Defendant to pay Court costs and all applicable surcharges and assessments to be collected during term probation.  If defendant is revoked, all applicable surcharges and assessments are to be collected by DOC from up to 25% of prison funds. Nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment
-Defendant is to provide a DNA sample and pay the related surcharge to be collected during term of probation. If defendant is revoked, all related surcharges are to be collected by DOC from up to 25% of prison funds; nonpayment penalty shall result in a civil judgment
-No new law violations rising to the level of probable cause
-Cooperate with agent
-Cooperate with any correctional programs recommended
-Follow all rules of probation and extended supervision
-Pay all supervision fees 
-Obtain/maintain employment 
-Obtain GED or HSED
-AODA assessment and any recommended treatment
-Absolute sobriety with random urine screens and breathalyzers
-No alcohol or controlled substances
-Defendant to perform 50 hours of community service
-Court allows transfer of probation to the State of Illinois
-As a condition of probation, Court ordered defendant serve 30 DAYS in the House of Corrections, straight time.  No good time credit.   Defendant to report to the House of Corrections on March 17, 2016 at 5:00 p.m.

AS TO COUNT 3:
The Court sentenced defendant to serve a term of IMPRISONMENT in the Wisconsin State Prisons for 3 1/2 YEARS.  INITIAL CONFINEMENT of 1 1/2 YEARS and EXTENDED SUPERVISION of 2 YEARS, with credit for 34 DAYS time served, concurrent with COUNT 1.  Court STAYED sentence and placed the defendant on PROBATION for a period of 2 YEARS with the following conditions for probation and extended supervision:
Defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and is not eligible for the Wisconsin Substance Abuse Program.  
-Restitution in the amount of $1,478.00 owed.  State to contact victims to determine who is owed restitution.   State also needs to provide the Court with extradition costs which will be added to the current amount of restitution owed.  
-Defendant to pay Court costs and all applicable surcharges and assessments to be collected during term probation.  If defendant is revoked, all applicable surcharges and assessments are to be collected by DOC from up to 25% of prison funds. Nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment
-Defendant is to provide a DNA sample and pay the related surcharge to be collected during term of probation. If defendant is revoked, all related surcharges are to be collected by DOC from up to 25% of prison funds; nonpayment penalty shall result in a civil judgment
-No new law violations rising to the level of probable cause
-Cooperate with agent
-Cooperate with any correctional programs recommended
-Follow all rules of probation and extended supervision
-Pay all supervision fees 
-Obtain/maintain employment 
-Obtain GED or HSED
-AODA assessment and any recommended treatment
-Absolute sobriety with random urine screens and breathalyzers
-No alcohol or controlled substances
-Court allows transfer of probation to the State of Illinois
